author: sky.cactus
content: There needs to be a list of signature first bytes.  In that list would include 0x19, 1,2,3, some RLP starters, etc.

author: sky.cactus
content: We just don't know where to put such a list, as Ethereum community doesn't have a good place for mutable lists.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Right, in that case the EIPs which would propose any signature which could conflict would need a thorough security analysis.

author: sky.cactus
content: There should be no double usage of leading bytes between EIPs.  The whole point is to avoid having to do that security analysis.

author: jochembrouwer
content: Right, well as far as I know the 0x19 message scheme is very widely spread and the standard to sign messages (I don't know why EIP 191 is still in draft) - if that is the case, then 0x19-prefixed transactions should be rejected for this reason.

content: I agree that 0x19 should be on the list.

author: sky.cactus
content: It is very bad for people to implement draft EIPs in production environments.  There is a reason EIPs go through phases, and it is partly to ensure they get proper feedback and people looking at them.

author: sky.cactus
content:
When people go and implement a production app based on a draft EIP there are two possible options:
1. The EIP cannot be changed because people already implement it.
2. The EIP does change and now you have a bunch of non-standard apps out there claiming to be compliant when they aren't.

author: sky.cactus
content: Both are bad situations for standardization, so people should not be building production software around draft EIPs.

author: sky.cactus
content: ERC20 has this exact problem.  It didn't get proper review before everyone can off and implemented it which has resulted in years of pain for the community.
